title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the average score for randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct on a standardized test with 5 possible answers for each question by randomly guessing?
What is the fundamental counting principle used to calculate the number of possible outcomes in a situation with multiple events?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiplying the number of possible outcomes for each event

options.label: B
options.text: Adding the number of possible outcomes for each event

options.label: C
options.text: Subtracting the number of possible outcomes for each event

options.label: D
options.text: Dividing the number of possible outcomes for each event

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected number of questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the probability of getting 1/5 of the questions correct on a 20-question test with 5 possible answers for each question by randomly guessing?
What is the number of possible combinations for a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting all questions correct on a standardized test by randomly guessing?
What is the average number of questions correct by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting a perfect score on a true/false quiz by guessing?
What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of official sources in journalism

options.label: B
options.text: The power of personal stories in connecting people

options.label: C
options.text: The need for a slow dance of information in journalism

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of conveying information quickly in journalism

multiple-choice.question: What is the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?
What type of sources provide facts and data?
What type of sources offer knowledge of the big picture?
What type of sources offer insight into the human aspect of a story?
How do journalists identify compelling stories?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking surprising questions and regarding stories as sacred

options.label: B
options.text: By using facts and data only

options.label: C
options.text: By using anecdotes and personal experiences

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of anecdotes and personal experiences in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: They make the story more relatable and memorable

options.label: C
options.text: They offer knowledge of the big picture

options.label: D
options.text: They offer insight into the human aspect of a story

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of artful solicitation of story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the story more relatable and memorable

options.label: C
options.text: It offers knowledge of the big picture

options.label: D
options.text: It delivers the narrative bond that connects people

multiple-choice.question: In what situations is conveying information quickly important in journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: When you need to know where the tornado will hit

multiple-choice.question: What is the luxury of personal stories in journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: A focus on facts and data

options.label: D
options.text: A focus on the big picture

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: What did Emily Dickinson say about the power of books?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a source of entertainment.

options.label: B
options.text: They can take us to new worlds and change our perspectives.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a waste of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key findings of researchers in psychology, neuroscience, child development, and biology?

options.label: A
options.text: Stories have no impact on our beliefs and values.

options.label: B
options.text: Stories shape our culture and influence our understanding of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: Stories are only for entertainment purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: Stories are a waste of time.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Samuel Richardson's "Pamela" on society?

options.label: A
options.text: It sparked intense debate and challenged traditional norms.

options.label: B
options.text: It had no impact on society.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a bestseller but had no significant impact.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a failure and had no impact.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key characteristics of a hero in Charles Darwin's theory of evolution?

options.label: A
options.text: Intelligence, swiftness, and adaptability to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the concept of a "shared quest"?

options.label: A
options.text: We are all individual heroes in our own stories.

options.label: B
options.text: We are members of a larger community working together towards a common goal.

options.label: C
options.text: We are all alone in the world and must fend for ourselves.

options.label: D
options.text: We are all equal and have the same abilities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the terrain changing in the context of storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: We need to keep walking in the same old shoes.

options.label: B
options.text: We need to start shopping for new boots that were made for walking into a new era.

options.label: C
options.text: We need to go back to the old ways of storytelling.

options.label: D
options.text: We need to forget about storytelling altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key themes of the novel "The Hunger Games"?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of individualism and self-reliance.

options.label: B
options.text: The dangers of capitalism and the importance of considering the greater good.

options.label: C
options.text: The power of love and relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of traditional values and norms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the novel "Uglies" in the context of storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes the idea that physical beauty is the most important thing in life.

options.label: B
options.text: It reflects the dangers of pursuing a perfect body and letting the media define what is beautiful.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no significant impact on society.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a waste of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the novel "Seekers"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a story about a group of animals fighting for survival in a harsh environment.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a story about a group of animals working together to understand the impact of global warming.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a story about a group of animals learning to live in harmony with each other.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a story about a group of animals fighting against a common enemy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final question posed in the text?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the most important thing in life?

options.label: B
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the meaning of life?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the purpose of storytelling?

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula for logarithms?
What is the pH of tears in our eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the temperature of the water

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the pH of the water

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the chlorine in the water

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the amount of water in the pool

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula for pH?

options.label: A
options.text: pH = log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration (H+)

options.label: B
options.text: pH = -log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration (H+)

options.label: C
options.text: pH = log base 10 of the pH

What is the value of log base 2 of 64?

What is the pH of a water sample with a hydrogen ion concentration of 0.0000000398?
Why is the pH of 8.4 uncomfortable for our eyes?

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What was the first known form of telling time?
What is the basis for scientific time today?
Why is it important to keep track of time?

options.label: B
options.text: To make communication with people all over the world easier

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of sundials?

options.label: B
options.text: They do not work during the night

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for special occasions

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the hourglass?

options.label: B
options.text: It was used in ancient Egypt

options.label: C
options.text: It was used in the 14th century

options.label: D
options.text: It was used in the 13th century

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between New York and Boston in terms of time?
How many time zones are there on land?
What is the purpose of time zones?

options.label: A
options.text: To make communication with people all over the world easier
